Dear Ms. Klinski:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
03/01/2022. Due to the violations, a written corrective action plan is required. It should
be noted that violations of any licensing statutes rules and are also violations of the
MISEP and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 For repeat violations, identify why the previous CAP was unsuccessful.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular license will be issued. If
you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action will result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (269) 337-5289.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the
following:
R 400.4111 Job description.
An institution shall provide a job description for each staff
position that identifies rules, required qualifications, and lines of
authority.
One applicable new employee file (nurse) contained a job description, but the
employee did not meet the educational requirements for the job. REPEAT
VIOLATION, Renewal Report, 07/21/21, and corresponding CAP, 08/11/21, and
Renewal Report, 07/14/20, and corresponding CAP, 07/14/20. The facility must
identify why the previous CAPs failed and how they will ensure compliance.
Despite the repeat violation, this is an improvement from the last inspection where
there were three missing job descriptions, and none were missing this time.
R 400.4113 Employee records.
An institution shall maintain employee records for each
employee and shall include documentation of all of the following
information prior to employment or at the time specified in this
rule:
(c) Verification of high school diploma or GED when
specified by rule.
(e) Three dated references which are obtained prior to
employment from persons unrelated to the employee and which
are less than 12 months old.
(f) A record of any convictions other than minor traffic
violations from either of the following entities:
(i) Directly from the Michigan state police or the
equivalent state law enforcement agency, Canadian province, or
other country where the person usually resides or has resided in
the previous 5 years.
(ii) From an entity accessing either Michigan state police
records or equivalent state, Canadian provincial, or other
country law enforcement agency where the person usually
resides or has resided in the previous 5 years.
(g) If the employee has criminal convictions, the institution
shall complete a written evaluation of the convictions that
addresses the nature of the conviction, the length of time since
the conviction, and the relationship of the conviction to regulated
4

activity for the purpose of determining suitability for employment
in the institution.
(h) A statement from the employee regarding any
convictions.
(c) One of nine new employee files reviewed did not contain documentation of
education. REPEAT VIOLATION, Renewal Report, 07/21/21, and corresponding
CAP, 08/11/21, and Renewal Report, 07/14/20, and corresponding CAP,
07/14/20. The facility must identify why the previous CAPs failed and how they
will ensure compliance. Despite the repeat violation, this is an improvement from
the last inspection where there were 29 of 34 educational records missing.
(e) One of nine new employee files reviewed contained only two of the three
required references. REPEAT VIOLATION, Renewal Report, 07/21/21, and
corresponding CAP, 08/11/21. The facility must identify why the previous
CAPs failed and how they will ensure compliance. Despite the repeat violation,
this is an improvement from the last inspection where there were seven of 38 files
with missing or had undated references.
(f) Two of nine new employee files reviewed contained criminal history checks that
were done four and five months after hire, not prior to hire. REPEAT VIOLATION,
Renewal Report, 07/21/21, and corresponding CAP, 08/11/21, and Renewal
Report, 07/14/20, and corresponding CAP, 07/14/20. The facility must identify
why the previous CAPs failed and how they will ensure compliance. Despite
the repeat violation, this is an improvement from the last inspection where there
were 16 missing clearances and none missing in this review.
(g) Two of nine new employee files reviewed were observed to have criminal
histories that included convictions other than minor traffic violations. There was no
written evaluation of the convictions by the facility. REPEAT VIOLATION, Renewal
Report, 07/21/21, and corresponding CAP, 08/11/21. The facility must identify
why the previous CAPs failed and how they will ensure compliance.
(h) Two of nine new employee files reviewed were observed to have criminal
histories that included convictions other than minor traffic violations. There were no
written statements from the employees regarding the convictions.
R 400.4114 Tuberculosis screening for employees and volunteers.
The licensee shall document, prior to employment, that each
employee and volunteer who has contact with residents 4 or
more hours per week for more than 2 consecutive weeks is free
from communicable tuberculosis. Freedom from communicable
tuberculosis shall be verified within the 1-year period before
5

employment and shall be verified every 1 year after the last
verification or prior to the expiration of the current verification.
Five of sixteen employee files were found to have late or overdue tuberculosis
screenings. REPEAT VIOLATION, Renewal Report, 07/21/21, and corresponding
CAP, 08/11/21, and Renewal Report, 07/14/20, and corresponding CAP,
07/14/20. The facility must identify why the previous CAPs failed and how they
will ensure compliance. Despite the repeat violation, this is an improvement from
the last inspection where there were 18 employee files with missing or late
tuberculosis screenings.
R 400.4128 Initial staff orientation and ongoing staff training.
(4) Training opportunities for direct care staff shall include, but
are not limited to, all of the following:
(g) Proper and safe methods and techniques of restraint and
seclusion if the agency has an approved seclusion room.
One of sixteen employee files reviewed did not contain documentation of restraint
training.
R 400.4142 Health services; policies and procedures.
(1) An institution shall establish and follow written health service
policies and procedures addressing all of the following:
(e) Dispensing medication.
Three of three current resident files reviewed contained medication administration
records that were missing documentation for multiple medications on multiple days
for the two months reviewed (December 2021 and January 2022). The forms
contained no reason for why medications were not passed.
R 400.4156 Institutions not detention institutions or shelter care
institutions; updated treatment plan.
(3) The updated treatment plan shall include all of the following
information:
(a) Dates, persons contacted, type of contact, and place of
contact.

(a) Three of three current youth files reviewed were found not to have social work
contacts in the updated treatment plans reviewed. The contacts were completed and
provided for review after the inspection, but were not part of the plans as required.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that there
are additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The
facility is in compliance will all additional MISEP requirements reviewed.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHHS Contract/Policy violation. Please
note that there are additional DHHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be
included in section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHHS
Contract/Policy requirements except for the following:
RFCJJ Contract Oct 17: Prison Rape Elimination Act & Sexual Abuse
Prevention & Response Overview.
One of nine new employee files reviewed was observed to have received PREA
training late: 2 ½ months after hire. REPEAT VIOLATION, Renewal Report,
07/21/21, and corresponding CAP, 08/11/21. The facility must identify why the
previous CAPs failed and how they will ensure compliance. Despite the repeat
violation, this is an improvement from the last inspection where there were five
employee/intern files with no documentation of PREA training.
RFCJJ Contract Oct 17: Annual Trauma Focused Training
Six of six applicable existing employee files reviewed did not document annual
trauma training. REPEAT VIOLATION, Renewal Report, 07/21/21, and
corresponding CAP, 08/11/21. The facility must identify why the previous
CAPs failed and how they will ensure compliance.
RFCJJ Contract: Screening and Assessment: The Contractor must be trained
in and utilize the screening and assessment tools as required and within the
timeframes identified by MDHHS Juvenile Justice Residential (JRM) policy
manuals. (See JRM 202 RESIDENTIAL SCREENING AND ASSESSMENTS: Sex
Offender Assessments)
Two of two applicable youth files reviewed did not contain documentation of use
of a sex offender assessment tool as outlined in contract and policy. The facility
reported that they were administering the assessment at a certain stage of their
program. This is not in line with the required timeframes. REPEAT VIOLATION,
Renewal Report, 07/21/21, and corresponding CAP, 08/11/21. The facility
must identify why the previous CAPs failed and how they will ensure
compliance. Despite the repeat violation, this is an improvement from the last
inspection where there was a missing screening for one youth. In this review, the
screening tools were found to be used, but not in the correct timeframe.
7

RFCJJ Contract: Treatment Plans
The Contractor must conduct individualized youth treatment planning in
accordance with JRM 201, Residential Treatment Plans, Reentry Plans and
Release Reports and linked policies.
Two of three current youth files contained updated treatment plans that did not
have the youth signature.
RFCJJ Contract The Contractor shall ensure that applicable CCI staff has access
to the Michigan Statewide Automated Child Welfare Information System
(MiSACWIS) through a web-based interface, henceforth referred to as the
“MiSACWIS application.”
Reporting:
4) The Contractor must maintain youth case record in accordance with the
administrative rules for Child Caring Institutions, Mich Admin Code R
400.4101-4666 and must be responsible for maintaining an up-to-date
electronic case record for juvenile justice MDHHS-supervised youth in
the MiSACWIS system including, but not limited to:
f) Social Work Contacts.
g) Clinical Case Notes.
h) Treatment Plans and Release Reports (Mich Admin Code R
400.4155-400.4156).
i) Assessments and Assessment Scores.
The facility is noncompliant with the contract as the clinical staff have not been
entering or uploading all required documentation to MiSACWIS. This includes
social work contacts, clinical case notes, treatment plans, release reports,
assessments and assessment scores as observed. Treatment plans and release
reports were completed on Word documents instead of in the system. The facility
provided some documentation of having contacted MiSACWIS helpdesk for
assistance, however, this issue has been ongoing for an extended period, and it
does not appear the facility administration ensured that the staff were appropriately
set up in the system once previous staff, who had access, left. Some functionality
has been restored but they are still working to get cases assigned in order to be
fully operational. The CAP for this item must report how the facility is going ensure
all applicable staff get the access they need in a timely manner and include a plan
for ensuring ongoing access should staff turnover.
8

IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
R 116(2)(a): The Chief Administrator did one annual assessment from 10/01/19-
10/01/20 and then did the next 01/01/21-12/31/21, which resulted in omitting October,
November and December 2020 from the most recent review. The last assessment
contained an in-depth review, but the Chief Administrator must ensure there are no
gaps if changing the period.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
It is highly recommended that all employees are certified in CPR and First Aid.
It was recommended that upon return to a regular license status, and the facility
placement suspension lifted, that the facility administration work strategically with
MDHHS as they begin taking new placements again, to ensure there is sufficient
staffing to comply with ratio and safety standards.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There was one incident of substantiated child abuse and/or neglect and
corporal punishment during this licensing period (same incident).
The substantiated child abuse and the substantiated use of corporal punishment
occurred in the same incident. SIR 2022C0207002, 11/17/21, and corresponding
CAP, signed 12/16/21, noted a violation for R 158(2) for using corporal punishment.
In this case, the involved staff acknowledged biting the youth during the incident when
the youth attacked her as a reflexive/instinctive reaction instead of using her Handle
with Care training. The facility was also cited for R 112(4) as this staff demonstrated
she was not able to perform her job duties. Additionally, the DHHS Specialist deemed
the staff unsuitable. Finally, the facility was cited for R 131 as they failed to report the
incident to Centralized Intake. The involved staff was terminated, and the facility
implemented trainings on mandated reporting and use of physical management. They
have been compliant with their CAP terms thus far as evidenced in their records and
documentation.
The facility had only one investigation during this period under review
(compared to 42 in the 18 months prior to this). They submitted 4 acceptable
corrective action plans not related to maltreatment during this licensing period
(3 were for investigations completed during the prior licensing period).
SIR 2021C0207030, 11/01/21, and corresponding CAP, signed 12/16/21, found the
facility in violation of R 150(3) due to not reporting an AWOL youth per the rule
9

requirement. This youth did not return to the facility from a home pass. The facility
has completed the CAP.
SIR 2021C0207029, 11/03/21, and corresponding CAP, signed 12/16/21, cited three
sections of R 159 in violation of restraint requirements. In this incident the youth’s
behaviors, although escalated, did not present an immediate risk of injury to anyone.
The staff were observed providing space for Youth A until Youth A squirted
mayonnaise on a manager. This does not qualify as justification for physical restraint.
Additionally, the manger was observed on the video review to not use proper Handle
with Care technique during the escort to the youth’s room. The manager was
observed with his arm over the youth’s shoulder at one point and grabbing the back of
the youth’s jumper as well. Another staff was also observed grabbing the youth by the
back of his jumper. The two staff pushed the youth into his bedroom. An escort is
permitted but the youth must be walking on their own and not being forced to move
while resisting, as occurred in this instance. The staff should have put the youth in a
proper two person standing restraint until he was cooperative to walk. Additionally,
this restraint incident report was completed by a manager and should have been
reviewed prior to submission. If a proper review had occurred, the non-compliances
could have been addressed by the facility. The facility was also cited for a violation of
their contract due to not providing all required therapy sessions and not documenting
therapy sessions. Additionally, the facility was cited for R 109(1)(c) because they did
not follow their phone call policy as they were monitoring youth phone calls with
workers. Finally, the facility was cited for R 132(1) for not replacing one missing
grievance box on one pod, nor a damaged grievance box on another pod. This CAP
is being actively monitored and thus far, the facility is compliant.
SIR 2022C0207002, 11/17/21, and corresponding CAP, signed 12/16/21-see notes in
above section.
SIR 2022C0207010, dated 01/05/22, with corresponding CAP, signed 02/17/22,
noted a violation for a repeat violation of R 131 as four staff had knowledge of the
youth’s allegation that a staff touched him inappropriately and did not report it to
Centralized Intake. The incident was eventually reported, when the youth mentioned it
to a DHHS PREA analyst who told the Director. The CAP was approved 02/22/22 and
will be monitored for compliance during the upcoming biweekly visits and quarterly
CAP reviews. Although this was a repeat violation for a safety related rule, additional
adverse licensing action was not recommended due to the overlapping timeframe of
the repeat violation, the recent approval of the previous CAP, as well as the change in
leadership that occurred in October 2021 which has markedly improved the culture
and compliance for the program.
During this period, the facility has changed Directors and there is a notable
improvement in oversight and accountability which has improved the programming
and decreased complaints, restraints, and seclusions. During this period there were
only 12 restraints and 2 seclusions. All restraints are reviewed for documentation and
there has been improvement in the content and accuracy of the documentation.
10

Weekly visits have been occurring since June 2021 and were reduced to biweekly in
January 2022 due to the progress at the facility. During these visits interviews were
done with youth and staff at all levels and typically includes direct care staff. During
this inspection, the interview focus was on administrative and supervisory staff. Youth
are consistently reporting increased programming and use of the facility services,
consistent individual and group therapy sessions, improved facility maintenance, and
increased communication with staff and administration. The student council has been
reinstituted and the youth report participating, feeling concerns are heard and
addressed, and indicate the climate in the program has improved. Staff interviews
included staff in various positions and levels of authority. Staff morale appears
improved with fewer complaints, although staff report increased wages is still their
number one need. There have been no observed or reported issues with maintaining
ratio. The Director reports that some mandatory overtime continues when needed,
but they are monitoring who they keep over to reduce burnout and fatigue.
The facility has improved in their implementation of CAPs and in the transparency
with the Department. They have been working on several active CAPs from the prior
period and have completed the majority of them during this period. Areas of focus
were proper restraint methods and use of verbal de-escalation, mandated reporting
requirements, maintaining ratio, staff supervision, and following facility policies. To
address these issues numerous staff trainings have occurred, meetings are
structured to address the issues and provide oversight, the quality assurance
manager has been enlisted to provide additional oversight to various areas, and the
new Director has provided increased structure, reinstituted programming, ensures
follow through, and requires accountability. Additionally, they have resolved physical
plant issues that resulted in prior violations. The work and completion of these CAPs
appears to have made a direct positive impact on the program as evidenced by the
reduced number of investigations and violations in this period (one new complaint this
period). They have also actively participated with the Residential Collaboration and
Technical Assistance Unit, and that has been reported as a successful and beneficial
partnership by both the RCTAU staff and the facility administration.
The Chief Administrator Annual Assessment was thorough and identified ongoing
needs within the program. Although this inspection report outlines a number of
violations, there are 15 in this report when compared to 22 in the last report. There
are also several repeat violations, but the number of occurrences on most were
significantly lower than the last inspection. Five of the violations were for an isolated
incident that was found in one applicable file. Employee files were markedly
improved, although violations continued. The clinical team had significant turnover
and resulted in MiSACWIS access issues which directly impacted their performance
as well. In summary, the facility has been observed making significant efforts to
improve their compliance and improve their services. Ongoing monitoring of CAP
compliance will continue to assist them in their follow through.
11

VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon
receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility will
be issued a renewal of their regular license.
